text: calling all chili lovers today's recipe
is just for you it's a chicken and white
bean chili
these are boneless skinless chicken
thighs so they don't add a lot of fat
but the chicken thighs do stay moist
during cooking which is what I love
about them so Brown these guys up it's
two pounds of boneless skinless thighs
that have been seasoned Brown it in two
tablespoons of olive oil and then add
one chopped onion white onion or yellow
onion and this is two diced poblano
chilies one tablespoon of chopped garlic
and then per use you want to get these
softened up and also get the browned
bits from browning the chicken off the
bottom of the pan once your peppers and
onions have gotten a little soft you can
add your spices and fry them up this is
one and a half teaspoons of cumin and
then same amount of coriander one and a
half teaspoons and two teaspoons of
chili powder fry that up if your pot is
too dry add a drizzle of oil that's what
I always do I don't like my spices to
burn so add a little more you can always
skip it off at the end if you want to
don't forget to season with some salt
but don't overdo it because you're gonna
use canned broth which has salt in it
usually this is one can of chopped
chilies they're four ounce cans that's
the size they always come in now you can
put the chicken back in your pot the
juices that are on the pan that the
chickens been sitting on you can add
that and then add four cups of
low-sodium or homemade chicken broth and
then you bring it to a boil and then
cover it and cook it until the chicken
is cooked through and the juices have
thickened etc just a little bit takes
only about 15 minutes when the stew has
simmered until the chicken is tender you
can remove the chicken and then shred it
into bite-sized pieces you can do that
with two forks if you want I have some
already shredded so just add that to the
rest of the chicken that's shredded
shoes like this are so great because
they freeze really well they're really
great heated so you can take some to
work later in the week to thicken it a
little bit I have three tablespoons of
cornmeal to that add about a cup of hot
liquid and
wisk the cornmeal back into the soup and
then simmer until the soup thickens just
a little bit maybe five minutes after
it's simmered for about five minutes
return the chicken and then add two cans
of drained white beans you see the nice
silkiness that you get from that
cornmeal it's subtle but it adds a
really nice thickness and then garnish
as desired of course I'm gonna add
tortilla chips cilantro and a spoon sour
cream and this is for everybody else but
me because I don't really like sour
cream on these things but go ahead and
give it a try mmm just a little bit
spicy but so so hearty and delicious
you're gonna be eating this all winter
you
